frameDefinitions: A Location is characterized by a high amount of (often goal-oriented)
An Entity stands out perceptually in comparison to other members of its type.
A Location is filled or covered with the Theme.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
A Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a Source to a Goal with some Path.
frameExamples: Pilot Mountain in NC is very <t>prominent</t>.
The waters of the bay <t>teemed</t> with fish.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
Emails from so-called Nigerian princes <t>flooded</t> inboxes all over the US.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Location</fen> where a lot of activity is taking place, or prototypically takes place.
The <fen>Activity</fen> that is conceptually filling the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Individuals</fen> are engaged in the <fen>Activity</fen>, creating a lively <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Location</fen> is characterized by a lot of activity.
The larger or general area where the <fen>Location</fen> is lively.
The <fen>Entity</fen> for which the saliency <fen>Attribute</fen> is appropriate and under consideration.
The feature of the <fen>Entity</fen> which is under discussion, namely perceptual salience.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Entity</fen> is in the state of having  a particular salience.
This role refers to the location where the <fen>Entity</fen> has a prominence of some <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The <fen>Theme</fen> covers or fills the <fen>Location</fen>.  This role most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with or in.
<fen>Location</fen> is the object or area that the <fen>Theme</fen> fills or covers.  This frame element generally occurs as the External Argument.
The period of time during which the the Abounding_with event occurs.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The mass of entities which moves.
The place where the overall motion event takes place, thus including Source, Path, and Goal locations.
The Source is the location the Theme occupies initially before its change of location.
Path refers to (a part of the) ground the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels by.
Goal is the location the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> ends up in.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the <fen>Mass_theme</fen>, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
When the event occurs.
The spatial setting in which the Mass_motion takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>On this side of town</fex> the streets are livelier.
If you are asked to search for the plus sign with red-vertical and green-horizontal elements, <fex>all the red and green plus signs</fex> may seem to become salient.
The diagram, (a frequency distribution chart) shows a <fex>prominently</fex> conspicuous region of stars that extend from the extremely bright and hot stars to the faint and cool variety.
The affection for American culture seemed more prominent <fex>last year</fex>.
The waters of the bay teemed <fex>with fish</fex>.
<fex>The walls</fex> crawled with nanite surveillance probes.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
Letters streamed in <fex>all over the country</fex>.
Afterwards, the crowd flooded <fex>away from the ceremony</fex>.
The door opened , and a crowd of people flooded <fex>past me</fex>, into the hall.
<fex>In the main auditorium</fex> people crowded around Orange's newest computer
